section.title: Differential forms

introduction.p: As we have seen, much of multivariable calculus is concerned with linearization of non-linear functions. This is done by placing a vector space T_p V, the tangent space, at every point in the space we're interested in. What we have witnessed in the prior sections is a way to take any space and build new ones such as multilinear k-forms or exterior algebras. The idea of differential forms is to build such new vector spaces at every point and consider fields of forms as we have considered vector fields when studying differential equations.

section.p: Let us observe an application of exterior products and this proposition right now. To do this, we need to define differential forms.

statement.p: Let U be an open subset of \mathbb{R}^m. A differential 1-form \eta on U is a smooth assignment which takes p to a tangent covector \eta (p) \in T^*_p \mathbb{R}^m. A differential k-form is a linear combination of k-exterior products of 1-forms or, equivalently, a smooth assignment to alternating k-forms on the tangent spaces.

section.p: Equivalently, we may consider a differential k-form to be an assignment from p to the dual of the k-th exterior space \bigwedge^k V, i.e. a vector in \text{Hom} (\bigwedge^k T_p \mathbb{R}^m , \mathbb{R}). Differential 1-forms are dual to vector fields in that if we have a vector field \mb{Y} on U and a differential one form \eta on U then \eta (\mb{Y}) is a scalar function on U. The most common way to create a differential 1-form is to take the derivative of a scalar function!

statement.p:
If U is an open subset of \mathbb{R}^m and p \in U, write the standard dual basis of T_p^* \mathbb{R}^m as
\tder{}{x_1}, \ldots, \tder{}{x_m}.
I.e. these are the dual vectors to the standard tangent vectors \partial_1 , \ldots, \partial_m in that
\tder{}{x_i} (\partial_j) = \begin{cases} 1 \amp \text{ if } i = j, \\ 0 \amp \text{ otherwise} \end{cases}
The (exterior) derivative of a scalar function is then defined as the differential 1-form
\tder{}{f} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} \tder{}{x_1} + \cdots + \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_n} \tder{}{x_n} .

section.p:
The student should note that this is really nothing new (yet), just a different way of expressing the usual derivative of an ordinary scalar function. For example, if we take
f(x,y) = x^2 \ln y
then the original definition of the derivative of f(x,y) at (x,y) is a linear transformation from T_{(x,y)} \mathbb{R}^2 to T_{x^2 \ln y} \mathbb{R}. Using the standard basis of vector fields, we identify these tangent spaces with \mathbb{R}^2 and \mathbb{R} and write this derivative as the 1 \times 2 matrix
\tder{}{f} = \left[ \begin{matrix} 2x \ln y \amp \frac{x^2}{y} \end{matrix} \right].
As a differential 1-form, this is written
\tder{}{f} = 2x \ln y \,\tder{}{x} + \frac{x^2}{y}\, \tder{}{y}.
We will see differential forms in much more detail later on as they form the heart of multivariable calculus. For now, let us use them to re-express Lagrange multipliers.

proposition.title: Lagrange multipliers with one constraint - exterior product version

statement.p: Suppose V is an open set in \mathbb{R}^n, g : V \to \mathbb{R} and f: V \to \mathbb{R} two differentiable scalar functions. If X is the level set of g then a smooth point q \in X is a critical point of f|_X if and only if the differential 2-form \tder{}{f} \wedge \tder{}{g} vanishes at q.

section.p: The major advantage of this over the previous version is that there are no multipliers! Thus we have automatically eliminated one variable that needs to be solved in the previous version. Let's take another look at but using this technique.

statement.p:
Recall that in we wanted to find critical points of f(x,y,z) = x^2 - y^2 + z on the hyperboloid
g(x,y, z) = x^2 + y^2 - 4 z^2 = 1.
We compute derivatives but now write them as differential 1-forms to see
\tder{}{f} \amp = 2x \,\tder{}{x} -2y \,\tder{}{y} + \tder{}{z}, \tder{}{g} \amp = 2x\,\tder{}{x} + 2y\,\tder{}{y} - 8z\,\tder{}{z}.
Now we compute the exterior product
\tder{}{f} \wedge \tder{}{g} \amp = ( 2x \,\tder{}{x} -2y \,\tder{}{y} + \tder{}{z}) \wedge (2x\,\tder{}{x} + 2y\,\tder{}{y} - 8z\,\tder{}{z}) , \amp = 4xy \, \tder{}{x} \wedge \tder{}{y} - 2x ( 1 + 8z )\, \tder{}{x} \wedge \tder{}{z} + 2y (8z - 1)\, \tder{}{y}\wedge \tder{}{z}.
For this 2-form to be zero, each of the coefficient functions must be zero. The coefficient 4xy is zero if and only if either x = 0 or y = 0. Again, the constraint g(x,y,z) = 1 implies not both can be zero. Consider both cases:
Suppose x = 0 and y \ne 0. Since x = 0, the \tder{}{x} \wedge \tder{}{y} coefficient is zero. Since y \ne 0 the \tder{}{y} \wedge \tder{}{z} coefficient being zero implies 8z - 1 = 0 so that z = 1/8.
Suppose y = 0 and x \ne 0. Since y = 0, the \tder{}{y} \wedge \tder{}{z} coefficient is zero. Since x \ne 0 the \tder{}{x} \wedge \tder{}{z} coefficient being zero implies 1 + 8z= 0 so that z = -1/8.
Putting these into the constraint then produces the critical points as before.

proposition.title: Lagrange multipliers with several constraints - exterior products version

statement.p:
Suppose V is an open set in \mathbb{R}^n, \mb{G} : V \to \mathbb{R}^k a differentiable vector valued function
\mb{G} (x_1, \ldots, x_n) = (g_1(x_1, \ldots, x_n), \ldots, g_k(x_1, \ldots, x_n))
with \tder{}{\mb{G}} of full rank and f: V \to \mathbb{R} a differentiable scalar function. If X is the level set of \mb{G} then a smooth point q \in X is a critical point of f|_X if and only if \tder{}{f} \wedge \tder{}{g_1}\wedge \cdots \wedge \tder{}{g_k} is zero at q.

section.p: Differential forms also exhibit naturality when it comes to functions between vector spaces.

Now, why do we consider this definition when it seems to just be a repeat of the prior definitions with a lot more vocabulary? The answer is manifold (pun), but one precise answer comes from considering how to transform differential forms.

statement.p:
Let D be a domain in \mathbb{R}^m with coordinates (u_1, \ldots, u_m) and E a domain in \mathbb{R}^n with coordinates (x_1, \ldots, x_n). If \mb{G} : D \to E is a smooth differentiable function given by
\mb{G} (u_1, \ldots, u_m) = (x_1 (u_1, \ldots, u_m), \ldots, x_n(u_1, \ldots, u_m))
and
\eta = \sum_{i_1 \lt \cdots \lt i_k} f_{i_1, \ldots, i_k} (x_1, \ldots, x_n)\, \tder{}{x_{i_1}} \wedge \cdots \wedge \tder{}{x_{i_k}}
is a differential k-form on E then the pullback of \eta to D via \mb{G} is the differential k-form \mb{G}^* \eta on E given by
\mb{G}^* \eta = \sum_{i_1 \lt \cdots \lt i_k} (f_{i_1, \ldots, i_k}\circ \mb{G}) (u_1, \ldots, u_m) \,\mb{G}^* \tder{}{x_{i_1}} \wedge \cdots \wedge \mb{G}^* \tder{}{x_{i_k}}.
Here \mb{G}^* \tder{}{x_i} is just the exterior derivative \tder{}{x_i(u_1, \ldots, u_m)}.

Suppose
\mb{G} (u,v) = (x(u,v) , y(u,v)) = (u^2 - v^2, 2uv)
is defined taking D = \mathbb{R}^2 to E = \mathbb{R}^2. Consider the 1-form
\eta = x \tder{}{x} + y \tder{}{y}
and the two form
\vol^{st} = \tder{}{x} \wedge \tder{}{y}.
We compute the pullbacks \mb{G}^* \eta and \mb{G}^* \vol^{st}. To do so, we first compute
\mb{G}^* \tder{}{x} = \tder{}{x(u,v)} \amp = 2 u \, \tder{}{u} - 2 v \, \tder{}{v}, \mb{G}^* \tder{}{y} = \tder{}{y(u,v)} \amp = 2 v\, \tder{}{u} + 2 u\, \tder{}{v}.
Then
\mb{G}^* \eta \amp = x(u,v) \mb{G}^* \tder{}{x} + y (u,v) \mb{G}^* \tder{}{y}, \amp = (u^2 - v^2) ( 2 u \,\tder{}{u} - 2 v \,\tder{}{v}) + 2uv (2 v\, \tder{}{u} + 2 u \,\tder{}{v}), \amp = 2 u (u^2 + v^2)\, \tder{}{u} + 2v ( u^2 + v^2 ) \,\tder{}{v}.
and
\mb{G}^* \vol^{st} \amp = \mb{G}^* \tder{}{x} \wedge \mb{G}^* \tder{}{y}, \amp = (2 u\, \tder{}{u} - 2 v\, \tder{}{v}) \wedge (2 v\, \tder{}{u} + 2 u\, \tder{}{v}), \amp = 4 (u^2 + v^2) \, \tder{}{u} \wedge \tder{}{v}.

section.p: Pullbacks satisfy some key properties that make them natural operations to consider.
